msgSnippet: Writing a TestSuiteBuilder that uses reflection might be a good idea, but wouldn t it be better if the functionality we need was built into JUnit? Could we add
messageBody:
Writing a TestSuiteBuilder that uses reflection might be a good idea, but
wouldn't it be better if the functionality we need was built into JUnit?

Could we add the functionality by extending TestSuite and using a
constructor like this:

OurTestSuite(java.lang.Class theClass, java.lang.Object
objectToTest); ?

James

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@...]
Sent: 09 August 2002 07:50
To: JUnit Yahoo Group
Subject: Re: [junit]


Of course, you could have a utility class, like a TestSuiteBuilder,
that will scan the classpath via reflection and build up the test
suite. The code is simple enough in Java (easier in Smalltalk though
:) that it shouldn't take more than a few minutes, make it 10 if you
write it test first. :)

=jason

On Thu, 08 Aug 2002 01:50:43 -0400, "J. B. Rainsberger"
<jbr@...> said:
> This message only has an HTML part -- this is a text generated
representation
>
>
> I say AbstractTestCase is your best bet. It removes the pain of
> calling
> addTestSuite(Class), from what I can see. You could always use Ruby to
> generate the test classes...
> Good luck.
> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
> On 2002-08-07 at 12:27 james.dobson@... wrote:
> >Hi Everyone,
> >
> >Is it possible to automatically add all the tests of a test class to
> a
> >suite
> >without using 'suite.addTestSuite(MyTest.class)'?
> >
> >I have a test class that can test a number of classes from the same
> >hierarchy. Let's say for arguments sake that I have created two
> child
> >classes (ChildA and ChildB) of type JTextComponent and both of them
> >override
> >a number of methods such as setText. I have a number of tests that
> test
> >the
> >newly overridden methods. I have created a constructor for the class
> that
> >looks something like this:
> >
> > public MyTest(String name, JTextComponent component)
> > {
> > super(name);
> > this.component = component;
> > }
> >
> >My problem is this: I want to run this test twice, once for childA
> and
> once
> >for childB. But I don't want to type in the tests individually e.g.
> >
> > public class MyTestClient
> > {
> > public static Test suite()
> > {
> > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> >
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new ChildA()));
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new ChildA()));
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new ChildA()));
> > ........
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new ChildA()));
> >
> > // Then the same for childB
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new ChildB()));
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new ChildB()));
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new ChildB()));
> > ........
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new ChildB()));
> > return suite;
> > }
> > public static void main(String[] args)
> > {
> >
> junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(MyTestClient.class);
> > }
> > }
> >
> >How I would like to write the suite method is something like this:
> >
> > public static Test suite()
> > {
> > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> >
> > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here to indicate
> I
> >want to test ChildA */)
> > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here to indicate
> I
> >want to test ChildB */)
> > }
> >
> >Hope this is a sensible question!
> >
> >James
